etymologies: mid 17th century: from re- (expressing intensive force or reversal) + act, originally suggested by medieval Latin react- ‘done again’, from the verb reagere

definitions: respond or behave in a particular way in response to something

examples.text: he reacted angrily to the news of his dismissal
the market reacted by falling a further 3.1%

shortDefinitions: respond or behave in particular way in response to something

definitions: respond with hostility, opposition, or a contrary course of action to

examples.text: they reacted against the elite art music of their time

shortDefinitions: respond with hostility, opposition, or contrary course of action

definitions: (of a person) suffer from adverse physiological effects after ingesting, breathing, or touching a substance

examples.text: many babies react to soy-based formulas

shortDefinitions: (of person) suffer from adverse physiological effects after ingesting, breathing, or touching substance

definitions: interact and undergo a chemical or physical change

examples.text: the sulfur in the coal reacts with the limestone during combustion

shortDefinitions: interact and undergo chemical or physical change

definitions: cause (a substance) to undergo a change by interacting with another substance.
shortDefinitions: cause substance to undergo such change by interacting with another substance

definitions: (of stock prices) fall or rise in reaction to events, developments, etc.
shortDefinitions: (of stock prices) fall or rise in reaction to events, developments, etc.
